div.p: THE SPANISH GIPSIE. As it was Acted (with great Applause) at the Privat House in DRURY-LANE, and SALISBURY COURT.
Written by THOMAS MIDLETON, Gent. AND WILLIAM ROWLEY. Gent.
LONDON, Printed by I. G. for Richard Marriot in St. Dunstans Church-yard, Fleetstreet, 1653.

list.item: Lewys, Son to De Castro, slaine by Alvarez.
Don John, Son to Francisco De Carcomo, and a Lover of Constanza.
Sancho, A foolish Gentleman, and Ward to Don Pedro.
Soto, A merry fellow his Man.
Alvarez, An old Lord disguised like the Father of the Gipsies.
Guiamara, Wife to Count Alvarez, and Sister to Fernando, disguised like the Mother of the Gipsies, and call'd by the Name of Eugenia.
Constanza, Daughter to Fernando, disguis'd like a young Spanish Gipsie, and call'd by the Name of Pretiosa.
Christiana, A Gentleman, disguis'd like a Gipsie.
Cardochia, A young Hostes to the Gipsies.

div.head: ACTUS PRIMUS.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: ROderigo.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Art mad?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes, not so much with Wine; its as rare to see a Spaniard a drunkard, as a Germane sober, an Italian no Whoremonger, an English man to pay his debts. I am no Borachia, Sack, Maligo, nor Canary breeds the Calenture in my braines, mine eye mads me, not my cups.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: What would'st have us do?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Doe?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: So far as tis fit for a gentleman wee'l venture.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I aske no more, I ha seen a thing has bewitched me, a delicate body, but this in the waste, Foot and Leg tempting, the Face I had a glimpse of: but the Fruit must needs be delicious, the Tree being so beautifull.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Prithee to the point.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here tis, an old Gentleman, (no matter who he is) an old Gentlewoman (I ha nothing to do with her) but a young creature that followes them, Daughter or Servant, or whatsoever shee be her I must have, they are comming this way, shall I have her? I must have her.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Thou speak'st impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Easie, easie, easie, i'le seize the young girle: stop you the old man, stay you the old woman.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I'le fly off with the young Bird, that's all, many of our Spanish Gallants act these merry parts every night, they are weak and old, we young and sprightly, will you assist me?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Troath Roderigo any thing in the way of honour.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: For a wench Man any course is honorable.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Nay not any, her Father, if he her Father may be noble.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I am as noble.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Would the adventure were so.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Stand close, they come.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis late would we were in Madrill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Go faster my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Clara, keep close.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, helpe!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Are you crying out? I'le be your Midwife.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What mean you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Villaines, Thieves, Murderers.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Do you know me? I am De Cortes, Pedro de Cortes!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: De Cortes, Diego, come away.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Clara, where is my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Clara I these Villaines
Have rob'd us of our comfort, and will, I feare,
Her of her honour.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This had not wont
To be our Spanish Fashion, but now our Gallants,
Our Gentry, our young Dons heated with Wine,
(A fire our Country-men doe seldome sit at)
Commit these outrages, Clara!— Maria,
Let's homeward, I will raise Madrill to finde
These traytors to all goodness, Clara.

div.stage: Ma. Clara. Exit. Enter Lewys and Diego.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh Diego I am lost, I am mad!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So we are all.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis not with wine, i'me drunk with too much horror,
Inflam'd with rage, to see us two made Bawds
To Roderigo's lust, did not the old man
Name Decortes, Pedro de Cortes?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sure he did.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh Diego, as thou lov'st me, nay on the forfeit
Of thine own life or mine, seale up thy lips,
Let 'em not name De Cortes, stay, stay, stay,
Roderigo has into his Fathers house
A passage through a Garden.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thither I must finde Roderigo out,
And check him, check him home, if he but dare
No more; Diego along my soule does fight
A thousand battailes blacker then this night.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tho the black veyle of night hath over-clowded
The World in darknesse, yet e're many howers
The Sun will rise again, and then this act
Of my dishonor will appear before you;
More black then is the Canopy that shrowds it,
What are you, pray what are you?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Husht, a friend! a friend.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A friend, be then a gentle Ravisher,
An honorable villaine, as you have
Disroab'd my youth of natures goodliest portion,
My Virgin purity, so with your Sword
Let out that blood which is infected now,
By your soule-stayning lust.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Pish.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Are you noble?
I know you then will marry me, say.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not speak to me! are want on Divells dumbe?
How are so many harmelesse Virgins wrought
By falshood of prevailing words to yeild
To easie forfeits of their shames and liberty,
If every Orator of folly plead
In silence, like this untongu'd piece of violence?
You shall not from me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Phew no more.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You shall not,
Who e're you are, Disease of natures sloth:
Birth of some monstrous sinne, or scourge of virtue,
Heavens wrath and mankinds burthen, I will hold you,
I will, be rough and therein mercifull,
I will not loose my hold else.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: There, 'tis gold.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Gold, why! alas for what? the hire of pleasure,
Perhaps is payment, mine is misery;
I need no wages for a ruin'd name,
More then a bleeding heart.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay then y'are troublesome,
I'le lock you safe enough.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They cannot feare
Whom grief hath arm'd with hate and scorn of life.
Revenge I kneele to thee, alas 'gainst whom?
By what name shall I pull Confusion down
From Justice on his head that hath betrayd me?
I know not where I am, up I beseech thee
Thou Lady regent of the aire, the Moon,
And lead me by thy light to some brave vengeance,
It is a Chamber sure, the guilty Bed.
Sad evidence against my losse of honour
Assures so much, what's here, a window curtaine?
Oh Heaven! the stars appeare 'too, ha! a chamber,
A goodly one, dwells Rape in such a paradice!
Help me my quickned senses, 'tis a garden
To which this window guides the covetous prospect,
A large one and a faire one, in the midst
A curious Alablaster Fountaine stands,
Fram'd like-like what? no matter, swift remembrance,
Rich furniture within too! and what's this?
A precious Crucifix? I have enough,
Assist me oh you powers that guard the innocent.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Now!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Welcome, if you come arm'd in destruction,
I am prepar'd to die.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Tell me your Name,
And what you are.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You urge me to a sinne
As cruell as your lust, I dare not grant it,
Thinke on the violence of my defame,
And if you meane to write upon my Grave
An Epitaph of peace, forbear to question,
Or whence, or who I am; I know the heate
Of your desires are after the performance
Of such a hellish act, by this time drown'd
In cooler streams of penance; and for my part
I have wash'd off the Leaprosie that cleaves
To my just shame, in true and honest teares;
I must not leave a mention of my wrongs,
The staine of my unspotted birth to memory,
Let it lie buried with me in the dust,
That never time hereafter may report
How such a one as you have made mee live;
Be resolute, and do not stagger, doe not,
For I am nothing.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sweet let me enjoy thee
Now with a free allowance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ha, enjoy me!
Insufferable villaine!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Peace: speak low,
I meane no second force, and since I find
Such goodness in an unknown frame of virtus:
Forgive my soule attempt, which I shall grieve for
So hartily, that could you be your self
Eye-witness to my constant vow'd repentance,
Trust me you'd pitty me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, you can speak now.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So much I am the Executioner
Of mine own trespasse, that I have no heart,
Nor reason to disclose my name or quality;
You must excuse me that, but trust me (faire one)
Were this ill deede undone, this deed of wickednesse,
I would be proud to court your love like him,
Whom my first birth presented to the World: this for your satisfaction,
What remaines, that you can challenge as a service from me?
I both expect and beg it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: First, that you swear neither
In riot of your Mirth, in Passion
Of Friendship, or in folly of Discourse,
To speak of wrongs done to a ravish'd Maide.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: As I love truth I sweare.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Next that you leade me
Neere to the place you met me, and there leave me
To my last fortunes e're the morning rise.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Say more.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Lay a new man, if e're you marry
(Oh me! my heart's a breaking) but if e're
You marry in a constant love to her
That shall be then your Wife, redeem the fault
Of my undoing, I am lost for ever,
Pray use no more words.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You must give me leave
To veile you close.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do what you will, no time
Can ransome me from sorrows or dishonors,
Shall we now goe?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My shame may live without me,
But in my soul I beare my guilt about me,
Lend me your hand, now follow.

div.stage: Enter Lewys, Diego, and a servant.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Not yet come in, not yet?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No i'le assure your Lordship, I have seldom known
Him keep out so long, my Lord usually observes
More seasonable houres.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: On the stroake of three.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The stroake of three! 'tis wondrous strange!
Dost heare?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: E're six I will be here againe,
Tell thy Lord so: e're six,— a must not sleepe,
Or if a doe, I shall be bold to wake him:
Be sure thou tell'st him— doe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord I shall.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Diego.
Walke thou the street that leads about the Perado,
I'le round the West part of the City, meet me
At the Inquisition Chappell; if we misse him
Wee'l both back to his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: At the Chappell?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I there wee'l meete.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Agreed, I this way.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Shee is not noble, true, wise nature meant
Affection should enable her discent,
For love and beauty keeps as rich a seat
Of sweetnesse in the meane borne, as the great—
I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Tis Roderigo certainly,
Yet his voyce makes me doubt, but I'le o're-hear him

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That if only I should be the Man
Made accessary, and a party both
To mine own torment, at a time so neere
The birth of all those comforts I have travell'd with,
So many, many howers of hopes and fears;
Now at the instant— Ha, stand! thy name,
Truly and speedily.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Don Lewys!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The same; but who art thou— speake?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Tell mee,
As y'are a noble Gentleman, as ever
You hope to be enrowl'd amongst the vertuous,
As you love goodnesse, as you wish to inherit
The blessednesse and fellowship of Angels,
As you are my friend, as you are Roderigo,
As you are any thing that would deserve
A worthy name, where have you been to night?
Oh! how have you dispos'd of that faire Creature
Whom you led captive from me, speak, oh speak,
Where, how, when, in what usage have you left her?
Truth I require all truth.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Tho I might question
The strangenesse of your importunity;
Yet cause I note distraction in the height
Of curiosity, I will be plaine, and briefe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Instead of feeding
Too wantonly upon so rich a Banquet,
I found even in that beauty that invited me
Such a commanding majesty of chaste
And humbly glorious vertue, that it did not
More check my rash attempt, then draw to ebb
The float of those desires, which in an instant
Were cool'd in their own streames of shame and folly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Now all encrease of honours.
Fall in full showers on thee Roderigo,
The best man living.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You are much transported
With this discourse methinks.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yes, I am.
Shee tould yee her Name too.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I could not urge it
By any importunity.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Better still;
Where did you leave her?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Where I found her, farther
Shee would by no means grant me to waite on her,
Oh Luys I am lost.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This selfe-same Lady
Was shee to whom I have been long a Suiter,
And shortly hope to marry.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Shee your Mistris then? Luys, since friendship,
And noble honesty conjures our loves
To a continued league, here I unclaspe
The secrets of my heart. Oh I have had
A glimpse of such a Creature, that deserves
A Temple, if thou lov'st her, (and I blame thee not)
For who can look on her, and not give up
His life unto her service? if thou lov'st her,
For pitties sake conceale her; let me not
As much as know her Name, there's a temption in't,
Let me not know her Dwelling, Birth or Quality,
Or any thing that she calls hers, but thee
In thee my friend, I'le see her, and to avoyd
The surfeits and those rarities that tempt me,
So much I prize the happiness of friendship,
That I will leave the City.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Leave it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Speede me!
For Salamanca, court my studies now
For Phisick 'gainst infection of the minde.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You doe amaze me!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Here to live, and live
Without her, is impossible and wretched.
For Heavens sake never tell her what I was,
Or that you know me, and when I finde that absence
Hath lost her to my, memory, I'le dare
To see yee againe meane time the cause that drawes mee
From hence, shall be to all the World untol'd;
No friend but thou alone, for whose sake only
I undertake this voluntary exile
Shall be partaker of my griefes; thy hand
Farwell: and all the pleasures, joyes, contents
That blesse a constant Lover, henceforth crown thee
A happy Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You have conquer'd friendship
Beyond example.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! some one
That hath slept well to night, should a see mee
Thus merry by my selfe, might justly think
I were not well in my wits.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Diego!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes 'tis I, and I have had a fine fegary,
The rarest, Wild-goose chase.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thad made thee melancholy.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Don Roderigo here? 'tis well you met him;
For tho I mist him, yet I met an accident
Has almost made me burst with laughter.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'le tell you, as we parted, I perceiv'd
A walking thing before me strangely tickled
With rare conceited raptures, him I dogg'd,
Supposing 'thad been Roderigo landed
From his new Pinnace, deepe in contemplation
Of the sweet voyage he stole to night.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Y'are pleasant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Prithee who was't?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Y'are i' the right, not you indeed;
For 'twas that noble Gentleman Don John,
Son to the Counte Francisco de Carcomo.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: In love it seems.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes, pepperd on my life,
Much good may't do him, Ide not be so lind
For my Cap full of double Pistolets.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What should his Mistris be?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: That's yet a Riddle
Beyond my resolution, but of late
I have observ'd him oft to frequent
The sports the Gipsies newly come to th'City present.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis said there is a Creature with'em,
Tho young of years, yet of such absolute beauty,
Dexterity of wit, and generall qualities,
That Spaine reports her not without admiration.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Nor you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I not remember.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Why then you never saw the prettiest toy
That ever Sung or Danc'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is shee a Gipsie?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: In her condition, not in her complexion.
I tell you once more, 'tis a sparke of beauty
Able to set a World at gaze, the sweetest,
The wittiest rogue, shalls see 'em? they have fine gambolls,
Are mightily frequented, Court and City
Flock to 'em, but the Country does 'em worship.
This little Ape gets money by the sack full,
It troules upon her.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Will yee with us friend?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You know my other projects, sights to me
Are but vexations.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh you must be merry,
Diego, wee'l toth' Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Best take heed
You be not snap'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How snap'd?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: By that little Faire,
'Thas a shrewd tempting Face, and a notable Tongue.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I fear not either.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Goe then.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: will you with us?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I'le come after.
Pleasure and youth like smiling evills wooe us,
To taste new follies; tasted, they undoe us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come my brave boyes, the Taylors sheers has cut us into shapes fitting our Trades.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A trade free as a Masons.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A trade brave as a Courtiers, for some of them doe but shark, and so do we.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Gipsies, but no tann'd ones, no Red-oker rascalls umberd with soot and bacon as the English Gipsies are, that sally out upon Pullen, lie in ambuscado for a rope of Onions, as if they were Welsh Free-booters; no, our stile has higher steps to climbe over, Spanish Gipsies, noble Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I never knew nobility in basenes.

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.p: Basenes! the arts of Cocoquismo, and Germania us'd by our Spanish Pickeroes (I meane Filching, Foysting, Niming, Jilting) we defie; none in our Colledge shall study 'em, such Graduates we degrade.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am glad Spaine has an honest company.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Wee'l entertaine no Mounty-bancking Stroule,
No Piper, Fidler, Tumbler through small hoopes;
No Ape carrier, Baboon bearer,
We must have nothing stale, triviall or base:
Am I your Major domo, your Teniente,
Your Captaine, your Commander?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Who but you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: So then, now being enter'd Madrill the inchanted Circle of Spaine, have a care to your new Lessons.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Wee listen.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Plow deepe furrowes, to catch deep root in th' opinion of the best, Grandos, Dukes, Marquesses, Condes, and other Titulados, shew your sports to none but them, what can you doe with 3. or 4. Fooles in a dish, and a block-head cut into sippets?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Scurvy meate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The Lacedemonians threw their Beards over their shoulders, to observe what men did behinde them as well as before, you must do.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We shall never doo't, our muzzles are too short.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Be not English Gipsies, in whose companie a man's not sure of the eares of his head they so pilfer; no such angling; what you pull to Land catch faire; there is no Iron so foule but may be guilded, and our Gipsie profession how base soever in shew, may acquire commendations.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Gipsies, and yet pick no pockets?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Infamous and roguy, so handle your Webbs, that they never come to be woven in the Loome of Justice, take any thing that's given you, Purses, Knives, Handkerchers, Rosaries, Tweezes, any toy, any money, refuse not a Maruade, a blanck, Feather by Feather birds build Nests, graine peckd up after graine, makes Pullen fat.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The best is we Spaniards are no great feeders.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: If one City cannot maintaine us, away to another, our horses must have wings; does Madrill yeild no money? Sivell shall; is Sivell close fisted? Vallidoly is open; so Cordica, so Toledo: doe not our Spanish Wines please us? Italian can then, French can, preferments bow is hard to draw, set all your strengths to it, what you get, keep, all the World is a second Rochill, make all sure, for you must not look to have your Dinner serv'd in with Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, no, Sackbuts shall serve us.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.p: When you have money, hide it; sell all our horses but one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why one?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Tis enough to carry our apparell and trinkets and the lesse our ambler eates, our cheere is the better; none be sluttish, none theevish, none lazy, all Bees, no Drones, and our hives shall yeild us Honey.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: See Father, how I am fitted; how do you like This our new stock of cloaths?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My sweet Girle excellent; see their old robes be safe.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: That sir, I'le looke to,
Whilst in my house you lie, what thiefe so ever
Layes hands upon your goods, call but to me
I'le make the satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Thanks good Hostesse.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: People already throng into the Inne,
And call for you into their private rooms.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No Chamber Comedies, Hostesse plie you your tide; flow let 'em to a full Sea, but wee'l shew no pastime till after dinner, and that in a full ring of good people, the best, the noblest, no closset sweet meates, pray tell 'em so.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.p: How old is Pretiosa?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Twelve and upwards.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: I am in my teenes assure you Mother, as little as I am, I have been taken for an Elephant, Castles and Lordships offer'd to be set upon me, if I would beare 'em; Why your smallest Clocks are the pretiest things to carry about Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay Child thou wilt be tempted.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Tempted! tho I am no marke in respect of a huge But, yet I can tell you great bubbers have shot at me, and shot golden Arrowes, but I my selfe gave ayme, thus; wide, foure Bowes; short, three and a halfe; they that crack me shall finde me as hard as a Nut of Galisia, a Parrot I am, but my teeth too tender to crack a wantons Almond.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou art my noble Girle, amany Dons
Will not believe but that thou art a Boy
In Womens Cloaths, and to try that conclusion
To see if thou beest Alcumy, or no,
They'l throw down Gold in muffes, but Pretiosa
Let these proud Sakers and Jer-falcons flie,
Do not thou move a wing, be to thy selfe,
And not a changeling.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: How! not a Changeling!
Yes Father, I will play the changeling,
I'le change my selfe into a thousand shapes
To court our brave Spectators; I'le change my postures
Into a thousand different variations,
To draw even Ladies eyes to follow mine;
I'le change my voyce into a thousand tones
To chaine attention; not a changeling Father,
None but my selfe shall play the changeling.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt Pretiosa.
What noise is this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Here's Gentlemen swear all the oaths in Spaine they have seen you, must see you, and will see you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To drown this noyse let 'em enter.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Is your Play-house an Inne? a Gentleman cannot see you without crumpling his Taffaty cloake.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Nay more then a Gentleman, his man being a deminitive Don too.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Is this the little ape does the fine tricks?

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Come aloft Jack little ape!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Would my Jack might come aloft, please you to set the water Mill, with the Ivory cogs in't a grinding my handfull of purging comfetts.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: My Master desires to have you loose from your company.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Am I a Pigeon thinke you to be caught with Cummin-seeds? a flie to glew my wings to sweete-meates and so be tane?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: When do your gambolls begin?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Not till we ha din'd.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Foote then your bellies will be so full you'l be able to do nothing, Soto prithee set a good face on't for I cannot, and give the little Monkey that Letter.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Walke off and hum to your selfe: I dedicate (sweet destiny, into whose hand every Spaniard desires to put a Distaffe) these lines of Love.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: What Love, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Grave Mother Bumby the markes out a your mouth.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What's the Paper, from whom comes it?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: The comodity wrapd up in the Paper, are Verses, the warming Pan that puts heat into 'em, you fire-braind bastard of Helicon.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What's your Masters Name?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: His name is Don Tomazo Portacareco, Nunckle to young Don Hortado de Mendonza, Cosen german to the Conde de Tindilla, and naturall brother to Francisco de Bavadilla, one of the Commendadors of Aleantaro, a Gentleman of long standing.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Verses! I love good ones, let me see 'em.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Good ones! if they were not good ones, they should not come from mee, at the name of Verses I can stand on no ground.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Here's gold too, who's is this?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Whoe's but yours? if there been any fault in the Verses, I can mend it extempore; for a stich in a mans stocken not taken up in time ravells out all the rest.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Botcherly Poetry, botcherly.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Verses and gold! these then are golden Verses.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Had every Verse a Pearle in the eye it should be thine.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: A pearle in mine eye! I thanke you for that, doe you wish mee blinde?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I by this light doe I, that you may look upon nobodies crime but mine.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: I should be blind indeede!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray Sir read your Verses.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Shall I sing 'em or say 'em?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Which you can best.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Both scurvily.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I'le set out a throate then.
Oh that I were a Bee to sing
Hum buz, buz, hum, I first would bring
Home Honey to your Hive, and there leave my sting.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: He manders.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh that I were a Goose to feede
At your barne-dore, such Corne I need,
Nor would I bite, but Gozlings breede.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: And Ganders.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh that I were your Need'les eye,
How through your Linnen would I flie;
And never leave one stich awry!

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Hee'l towze yee.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh would I were one of your haires,
That you might combe out all my cares;
And kill the Nits of my despaires,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Oh Lowzie.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: How! Lowzie I can Rimes be Lowzie?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, no, th'are excellent.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But are these all your own?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Mine own! wud I might never see Inck drop out of the nose of any Goose quil more, if velvet Cloaks have not clap'd me for 'em, doe you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Past all compare, they shall be writ out
When y'have as good or better.
For these and those pray booke me down your debtor.
Your Paper is long liv'd, having two soules,
Verses and Gold.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Would both those were in thee pritty little body, sweets Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: A Pistolet and this Paper, 'twould choake me.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: No more then a bribe does a Constable; the Verses will easily into your head, then buy what you like with the Gold, and put it into your belly, I hope I ha chaw'd a good reason for you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Will you chaw my Jennet ready sir?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: And eate him down if you say the word. Exit.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Now the coxcombe my man is gon, because y'are but a Country company of Strowles, I thinke your stock is thred-bare, here mend it with this Cloake.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What do you meane sir?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: This Scarfe, this Feather, and this Hat.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Deare Signior.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If they be never so deare, pox 'o this hot Ruffe; little Gipsie, wear thou that.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your meaning sir.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: My meaning is not to be an Asse, to carry a burthen when I need not, if you shew your Gambols forty Leagues hence, I'le gallop to 'em; Farwel old Gray-beard, adue Mother mumble-crust, morrow my little Wart of beauty. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: So harvest will come in, such Sunshine days Will bring in golden sheafes, our Markets raise, Away to your taske. Exit. Don John pulls Pretiosa back.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Mother, Grand-mother!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Two rowes of Kindred in one mouth!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Be not uncivill sir, thus have you us'd her thrice.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Thrice! three thousand more: may I not use mine own?

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Your own! by what tenure?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Cupid entailes this Land upon me, I have wooed thee, thou are coy, by this aire I am a Bull of Tarisa, wild, mad for thee: you told I was some copper coyne, I am a Knight of Spaine, Don Francisco de Carcomo my Father, I Don John his Sonne, this paper tells you more, grumble not old Granam, (heere's gold) for I must by this white hand, marry this cherry-lip'd, sweet-mouth'd villaine.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: There's a thing call'd quando.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Art thou so willing?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Peace threescore and five.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Marry me! eate a Chicken e're it be out o'th shell! I'le weare no shackles, liberty is sweet; that I have, that I'le hold, marry me! can Gold and Lead mix together? a Dimond, & a button of Christal fit one ring? you are too high for me, I am too low; you too great, I too little.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I pray leave her sir, and take your Gold againe.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Or if you dote, as you say, let me try you do this.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Any thing, kill the great Turke, pluck out the Magul's Eyeteeth; in earnest Pretiosa any thing!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Your taste is soon set down, turne Gipsie for two years, be one of us, if in that time you mislike not me, nor I you, here's my hand farwell.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: There's enough for your Gold, witty Child. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Turne Gipsie I for two years! a capering Trade.
And I in th'end may keepe a dancing Schoole,
Having serv'd for't, Gipsie! I must turne,
Oh beauty! the Suns fires cannot so burne.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I have offended, yet oh Heaven! thou knowst
How much I have abhor'd even from my birth,
A thought that tended to immodest folly;
Yet I have fallen, thoughts with disgraces strive,
And thus I live, and thus I die alive.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Fie Clara, thou dost court calamity too much.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yes Girle, thou dost.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Why should we fret our eyes out with our teares?
Weary complaints, 'tis fruitlesse, childish,
Impatience, for when mischiefe hath wound up
The full weight of the Ravishers foul Life,
To an equall height of ripe iniquity,
The poyse will by degrees, sinke down his Soule
To a much lower, much more lasting ruine
Then our joynt wrongs can challenge.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Darknesse it selfe
Will change nights sable brow, into a Sun-beame
For a discovery, and be sure
When ever we can learne what monster 'twas
Hath rob'd thee of the Jewell held so precious,
Our vengeance shall be noble.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Royall, any thing;
Till then lets live securely: to proclaime
Our sadnesse were meere vanity.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A needs not,
I'le study to be merry.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: We are punish'd
Maria justly, covetousnesse to match
Our Daughter to that matchlesse piece of ignorance,
Our foolish Ward, hath drawn this curse upon us.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I feare it has!

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Off with this face of griefe.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Here comes Don Lewys; noble sir.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: My Lord,
I trust I have you and your Ladies leave
To exchange a word with your faire Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Leave and welcome, harke Maria, your eare too.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Mine my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Deare Clara, I have often su'd for Love,
And now desire you would at last be pleas'd
To stile me yours.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Mine eyes ne'r saw that Gentleman
Whom I more nobly in my heart respected,
Then I have you, yet you must Sir excuse me,
If I resolve to use a while that freedome
My younger dayes allow.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But shall I hope?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You will do injury to better fortunes
To your own Merit, Greatnesse, and Advancement,
Which I beseech you not to slack.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then heare me,
If ever I embrace another choyce,
Untill I know you elsewhere match'd, may all
The chiefe of my Desires finde scorne and ruine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh me!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why sigh you Lady?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Deede my Lord I am not well.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then all Discourse is tedious,
I'le chuse some fitter time; till when faire Clara.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You shall not be unwelcome hither sir;
That's all that I dare promise.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Diego!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What says Don Pedro?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Hee'l goe with you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Leave us:
Shall I my Lord, entreate your privacy?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Withdraw Maria, wee'l follow presently,

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The great Corigidor, whose politick streame
Of popularity, glides on the shore
Of every vulgar praise, hath often urged me
To be a Suitor to his Catholick Majesty,
For a repeale from banishment for him
Who slew my Father, complements in vowes,
And strange well studied promises of friendship,
But what is new to mee, still as he Courts
Assistance for Alvarez my grand enemy,
Still he protests how ignorant he is,
Whether Alvarez be alive or dead?
To morrow is the day we have appointed
For meeting at the Lord Francisco's house,
The Earle of Carcomo; now my good Lord,
The sum of my request is, you will please
To lend your presence there, and witnesse wherein
Our joynt accord consists.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You shall command it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But first as you are noble, I beseech you
Helpe mee with your advice, what you conceave
Of great Fernando's importunity,
Or whether you imagine that Alvarez
Survive or not?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: It is a question sir
Beyond my resolution, I remember
The difference betwixt your noble Father,
And Conde de Alvarez, how it sprung
From a meer trifle first, a cast of Hawks,
Whose made the swifter flight, whose could mount highest,
Lie longest on the wing. From change of words
Their controversie grew to blows, from blowes
To Parties, thence to Faction, and in short
I well remember how our streets were frighted
With brawles, whose end was bloud, till when no friends
Could mediate their discords: by the King
A reconciliation was enforc'd,
Death threaten'd the first occasioner
Of breach, besides the confiscation
Of Lands and Honours, yet at last they met
Againe; againe they drew to sides, renew'd
Their ancient quarrell, in which dismall uprore
Your Father hand to hand fell by Alvarez,
Alvarez fled, and after him the doome
Of exile was set out; He as Report
Was bold to voyce, retir'd himselfe to Rhodes,
His Lands and Honours by the King bestow'd
On you, but then an Infant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Ha, an Infant!

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: His Wife the sister to the Corigidor,
With a young Daughter, and some few that follow'd her
By stealth were shipt for Rhodes, and by a storme
Ship-wrack'd at Sea, but for the banish'd Conde,
'Twas never yet known what became of him,
Here's all I can informe you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: A repeale,
Yes, I will sue for't, beg for't, buy it, any thing
That may by possibility of friends,
Or Money, I'le attempt.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave charity.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Alas poore Lady, I could mourne for her!
Her losse was Usury more then I covet;
But for the Man, I'de sell my patrimony
For his repeale, and run about the World
To finde him out, there is no peace can dwell
About my Fathers Tombe, till I have sacrific'd
Some portion of revenge to his wrong'd ashes.
You will along with me?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: You neede not question it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I have strange thoughts about me, two such furies
Revell amidst my joyes as well may move
Distraction in a Saint, Vengance and Love,
I'le follow sir.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Pray lead the way: you know it.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: How now! from whence come you sir?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: From fleaing my selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: From playing with Fencers sir, and they have beat him out of his Cloaths sir.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Cloake, Band, Rapier, all lost at Dice!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nor Cards neither.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: This was one of my Masters dog-dayes, and he would not sweat too much.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It was mine own Goose, and I laid the Jiblets upon an other Coxcombs trencher, you are my Gardian, best beg me for a fool now.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: He that begs one begs tother.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Does any Gentleman give away his things thus?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes, and Gentlewomen give away their things too.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: To Gulls sometimes, and are Cony-catch'd for their labour.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Wilt thou ever play the Coxcombe?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: If no other parts be given me, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Thy Father was as brave a Spaniard
As ever spake the haute Castilian Tongue.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Put me in Cloaths, I'le be as brave as he.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: This is the ninth time thou hast plaid the Asse,
Flinging away thy trappings and thy cloath
To cover others, and goe nak'd thy selfe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I'le make 'em up ten, because I'le be even with you.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Once more your broken walls shall have new hangings.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: To be well hung, is all our desire.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: And what course take you next?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What course? why my man Soto and I wil go make some maps.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: What maps?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Not such Mapps as you wash houses with, but Mapps of Countries.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have an Unckle in Sivell, I'le go see him, an Aunt in Siena in Italy, I goe see her.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Cosen of mine in Rome, I goe to him with a Morter.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: There's a Curtizan in Venice, I'le goe tickle her.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Another in England; I'le goe tackle her.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: So, so, and where's the money to do all this?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If my wookes being cut down cannot fill this Pocket, cut 'em into Trapsticks.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: And if his Acres being sould for a Marvedi, a Turffe for markes in Cages, cannot fill this Pocket, give 'em to Gold-finders.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: You'l gallop both to the Gallowes, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And be hang'd you, new cloaths y'ad best.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Foure cloaks, that you may give away three, and keep one.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Wee'l live as merrily as beggers, lets both turne Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: By any means, if they cog wee'l lie, if they tosse wee'l tumble.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Both in a belly, rather then faile.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Come then, wee'l be Gipsified.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And tipsified too.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And we will shew such tricks, and such rare gambolls.
As shall put down the Elephant and Camels.

div.head: ACTUS TERTIUS.
div.stage: Enter Roderigo Disguiz'd like an Italian.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A thousand stings are in me! oh what vild prisons
Make we our bodies, to our immortall souls!
Brave Tenants to bad houses! 'tis a deare rent
They pay for naughty Lodging: the soule, the Mistresse,
The body, the Caroach that carries her,
Sinnes the swift wheeles that hurry her away;
Our Will the Coachman rashly driving on,
Till Coach and Carriage both are quite o're throwne;
My body yet scapes bruizes, that known thiefe
Is not yet cal'd toth' bar, there's no true sence
Of paine, but what the Law of conscience
Condemns us to, I feele that, who would loose
A Kingdome for a Cottage? an Estate
Of perpetuity, for a mans Life?
For annuity of that Life (pleasure) a sparke
To those Celestiall fires that burne about us!
A painted Star to that bright Firmament
Of constellations, which each night are set
Lighting our way, yet thither how few get?
How many thousand in Madrill drink off
The cup of lust, (and laughing) in one moneth
Not whining as I doe? should this sad Lady
Now meet me, do I know her? should this Temple
(By me prophan'd) lie in the ruines here,
The pieces would scarce shew her me:— would they did
Shee's Mistris to Don Lewys— by his steps,
And this disguise I'le finde her; to Salamanca
Thy Father thinks th'art gon; no close here stay
Where e're thou travell'st, Scorpions stop thy way: these.

div.stage: Enter Sancho, and Soto as Gipsies.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Soto, how doe I shew?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Like a rusty Armor new scour'd, but Master how shew I?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Like an Asse with a new pibal'd saddle on his back.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: If the Devil were a Taylor, he would scarce know us in these gaberdines.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If a Taylor were the Divel, I'de not give a Lowse for him, if he should bring up this fashion amongst Gentlemen, and make it common.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The freshnesse of the Morning be upon you both.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The saltnesse of the Evening be upon you single.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Be not displeas'd, that I abruptly thus
Breake in upon your favors, your strange habits
Invite me with desire, to understand
Both what you are, and whence, because no Country
(And I have measur'd some) shew me your like.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Our like! no we should be sorry, we or our cloaths should be like fish, new, stale, and stinking in three days.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If you aske whence we are, we are Egyptian Spaniards; if what, we are, ut, re, mi, fa, sol. Juglers, Tumblers, any thing any where, every where.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A good fate hither leades me by the hand,
Your quality I love, the scenicall Schoole
Has been my Tutor long in Italy,
(For that's my Country,) there have I put on
Sometimes the shape of a Comedian,
And now and then some other.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A Player! a brother of the tyring house.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Bird of the same feather.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Welcome, wut turne Gipsie?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I can nor Dance, nor Sing, but if my Pen
From my invention can strike Musick tunes,
My head and braines are yours.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Calves head and braines were better for my stomack.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A rib of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A modicum of the Muses, a horse-shooe of Helicon.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A Mag-py of Parnassin, welcome agen, I am a fire-brand of Phoebus my selfe, wee'l invoke together, so you will not steale my Plot.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fashion.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: But now adayes 'tis all the fashion.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What was the last thing you writ, a Comedy?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No 'twas a sad, too sad a Tragedy.
Under these eves I'le shelter me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: See here comes our company,
Doe our tops spinne as you would have 'em?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: If not whip us round.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I sent you a Letter to tell you we were upon a march.

div.stage: Enter Alvarez, Eugenia, Pretiosa, and the Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And you are welcome— yet these fooles will trouble us.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Rich fooles shall buy our trouble.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hang Lands, it's nothing but Trees, Stones and Durt, old Father I have Gold to keepe up our stock, pretious Pretiosa, for whose sake I have thus transform'd my selfe out of a Gentleman into a Gipsie, thou shalt not want sweete Rimes my little Musk-cat, for besides my selfe here's an Italian Poet, on whom I pray throw your welcomes.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Hee's welcome!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Sir, y'are most welcome, I love a Poet,
So hee writes chastely, if your Pen can sell me
Any smooth queint Romances, which I may sing,
You shall have Bayes and Silver.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Pretty heart no selling:
What comes from me is free.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And me too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We shall be glad to use you sir, our sports
Must be an Orchard bearing severall Trees
And Fruits of severall taste; one pleasure dulls.
A time may come, when we (besides these pastimes)
May from the Grandoes and the Dons of Spaine
Have leave to try our skill even on the Stage,
And then your witts may helpe us.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: They are your servants.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Trip softly through the streets, till we arrive
You know at whose house Father.

lg.l: Trip it Gipsies, trip it fine,
Shew tricks and lofty Capers;
At threading Needles we repine,
And leaping over Rapiers.
Pindy Pandy rascall toyes,
We scorne cutting Purses,
Tho we live by making noyse,
For cheating none can curse us.
Over High-wayes, over low,
And over Stones and Gravell,
Tho we trip it on the Toe,
And thus for Silver travell.
Tho our Dances waste our backs,
At night fat Capons mend them;
Eggs well brew'd in Butterd'-sack,
Our Wenches say befriend them.
Oh that all the World were mad,
Then should we have fine Dancing,
Hobby horses would be had,
And brave Girles keepe a prancing,
Beggers would on Cock-horse ride,
And Boobies fall a roaring,
And Cuckolds tho no Hornes be spide,
Be one another goring.
Welcome Poet to our Ging,
Make Rimes wee'l give thee reason,
Canary Bees thy braines shall sting
Mull-sack did ne're speake Treason.
Peter-see-me shall wash thy nowle,
And Malligo Glasses fox thee,
If Poet thou tosse not bowle for bowle
Thou shalt not kisse a Doxie.

div.stage: Enter Fernando, Francisco de Carcomo, Don Iohn Pedro, Maria, Lewys, and Diego.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lewys de Castro, since you circled are
In such a golden Ring of worthy friends,
Pray let me question you about that business
You and I last conferd on.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: My Lord I wish it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then Gentlemen tho you all know this man,
Yet now looke on him well, and you shall finde
Such mines of Spanish honor in his bosome,
As but in few are treasur'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh my good Lord!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hee's Son to that de Castro, o're whose Tombe
Fame stands writing a booke which will take up
The age of time to fill it with the stories
Of his great acts, and that his honor'd Father
Fell in the quarrell of those Families
His own, and Don Alvarez de Castilla.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: The volume of those Families is too large,
And too wide Printed in our memory.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Would it had ne're come forth.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: So wish we all.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But heer's a Son as matchlesse as the Father,
For hee mindes bravery: he lets blood his Spleene,
Teares out the Leafe in which the Picture stands
Of slaine de Castro, casts a Hill of Sand
On all revenge, and stifles it.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: 'Tis done nobly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For I by him am courted to sollicite
The King for the repeale of poore Alvarez,
Who lives a banish'd man some say in Naples,

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Some say in Arragon.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No matter where,
That Paper foulds in it my hand and heart,
Petitioning the royalty of Spaine
To free the good old man, and call him home;
But what hope hath your Lordship that these beames
Of grace shall shine upon me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The word Royall!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And that's enough.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then since this sluce is drawn up to encrease
The streame, with pardon of these honord friends
Let me set ope another, and that's this,
That you my Lord Don Pedro, (and this Lady
Your noble Wife) would in this faire assembly
(If still you hold me Tenant to your favor)
Repeale the promise, you so oft have made me,
Touching the beautious Clara for my Wife.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: What I possesse in her before these Lords
I freely once more give you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And what's mine?
To you (as right heire to it) I resigne.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What would you more?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What would I more? the tree bowes down his head
Gently to have me touch it, but when I offer
To pluck the fruite, the top branch growes so high
To mock my reaching hand, up it does flie;
I have the Mothers smile, the Daughters frown.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Oh you must wooe hard!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wooe her well shee's thine own.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: That Law holds not 'mongst Gipsies, I shoot hard,
And am wide off from the Marke.

div.stage: Enter Soto, with a Cornet in his hand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is this my Lord your Musick?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None of mine.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A crew of Gipsies with desire,
To shew their sports are at your Gates afire.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How, how, my Gates afire Knave!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Art panting? I am a fire I'me sure!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What are the things they doe?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: They Friske, they Caper, Dance and Sing,
Tell fortunes too (which is a very fine thing)
They tumble— how? not up and down
As Tumblers doe, but from Towne to Towne.
Anticks they have, and Gipsie-masking,
And toyes which you may have for asking;
They come to devoure, nor Wine, nor good Cheere,
But to earne money, if any be here.
(But being ask'd, as I suppose,
Your answer will be in your tother hose)
For there's not a Gipsie amongst'em that begs,
But gets his living by his Tongue and Legs.
If therefore you please Dons they shall come in,
Now I have ended, let them begin.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: I, I, by any means.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But fellow bring you Musick along with you too.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, both lowd Musick, and still Musick, the loud is that which you have heard, and the still is that which no man can heare. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A fine Knave.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is report of a faire Gipsie,
A pretty little toy, whom all our Gallants
In Madrill flock to looke on: this shee trow?
Yes sure 'tis shee— I should be sorry else.

div.stage: Enter Alvarez, Eugenia, Pretiosa, Roderigo, Sancho, Soto, and all the Gipsies.

lg.l: Come follow your Leader follow
Our Convoy be Mars and Apollo,
The Van comes brave up here,
Ans. As hotly comes the Reare.
Omn. Our Knackers are the Fifes and Drums,
Sa, sa, the Gipsies Army comes.
Horsemen we need not feare
There's none but footemen here;
The Horse sure charge without;
Or if they wheele about,
Omn. Our Knackers are the shot that flie
Pit a pat ratling in the Sky.
If once the great Ordnance play
That's laughing, yet runne not away;
But stand the push of Pike
Scorne can but basely strike.
Omn. Then let our Armies joyne and sing
And pit a pat make our Knackers ring.
Arme, Arme, what Bands are those?
They cannot be sure our foes;
Weele not draw up our force,
Nor muster any Horse,
Omn. For since they pleas'd to view our sight
Let's this way, this way, give delight.
A Councell of War lets call,
Looke either to stand or fall;
If our weake Army stands
Thanke all these noble hands;
Whose gates of Love being open throwne
We enter, and then the Town's our owne.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A very dainty thing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A handsome Creature.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Looke what a pretty pit there's in her chin.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Pit 'tis a Grave to bury Lovers in.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My Fathers disguise guard me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Soto, there's de Cortez my guardian; but he smells not us.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Peace brother Gipsie, wud any one here know his fortune?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good fortunes all of us.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: 'Tis I sir needs a good one, come sir what's mine?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Mine and my husbands fortunes keepe together,
Who is't tels mine?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I, I, hold up Madam, feare not your pocket, for I ha but two Hands.
sp.l: You are sad, or mad, or glad
For a couple of Cockes that cannot be had,
Yet when abroad they have pick'd store of grains
Doodle doo they will cry on your Dunghills againe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Indeed I misse an idle Gentleman,
And a thing of his a foole, but neither sad
Nor mad for them, would that were all the Lead
Lying at my heart.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What look'st thou on so long?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: So long I do you thinke good fortunes are fresh Herrings, to come in sholes? bad fortunes are like Mackerell at Midsummer, you have had a sore losse of late.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: I have indeed, what is't?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I wonder it makes you not mad; for
Through a gap in your Ground
Thence late hath been stole
A very fine Asse, and a very fine Fole,
Take heede for I speake not by habs and by nabs,
E're long you'l be horribly troubled with scabbs.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: I am now so, goe silly foole.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I ha gin't him.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh Soto, that Asse and Foale fattens me!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Mother of the Gipsies, what can shee do?
I'le have about with her.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I with the Gipsie Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To her Boy I

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: From you went a Dove away
Which e're this had been more white,
Then the silver Roabe of, Day,
Her Eyes the Moone has none so bright.
Sate shee now upon your hand
Not the Crowne of Spaine could buy it;
But 'tis flowne to such a Land,
Never more shall you come nie it;
Ha! yes if Palmestrie tell true,
This Dove agen may flie to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou art a lying Witch, I'le heare no more.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: If you be so hot sit, we can coole you with a Song.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And when that Song's done, wee'l heat you agen with a dance.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Stay deare sir, send for Clara, let her know her fortune:

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis too well known.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Twill make her merry to be in this brave Company.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Good Diego fetch her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What's that old man! has he cunning too?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: More then all we.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Has he! I'le try his Spectacles.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha! Roderigo there! the Scholler
That went to Salamanca, takes he degrees
I'th Schoole of Gipsies? let the fish alone,
Give him Line, this is the Dove, the Dove: the Raven
That Beldam mock'd me with.

sp.speaker: Low.
sp.l: What Wormes pick you out there now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This— when this Line the other crosses
Art tells me 'tis a booke of losses,
Bend your hand thus, Oh! here I finde
You have lost a Ship in a great winde.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Lying Rogue I ne're had any.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Harke, as I gather,
That great Ship was de Castro call'd your Father.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And I must hew that Rock that split him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nay and you threaten.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And what's Don John thy fortune? th'art long fumbling at it?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Shee tells me tales of the Moone sir.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: And now 'tis come to the Sun sir.
Your Sun wud ride, the youth wud runne,
The youth wud sayle, the youth wud flie;
Hee's tying a knot will ne're be done,
He shoots, and yet has ne're an eye.
You have two, 'twere good you lent him one,
And a heart too, for he has none.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hoyday, lend one of mine eyes!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: They give us nothing, hee'd best put on a bold face and ask it.

lg.l: Now that from the Hive
You gather'd have the Honey,
Our Bees but poorely thrive,
Unlesse the Bankes be sunny.
Then let your Sun and Moone
Your gold and silver shine,
My thanks shall huming fly to you.
Omnes .And mine, and mine, and mine.
See, see, your Gipsie toyes,
You mad Girles, you merry Boyes.
A boone voyage we have made
Loud Peales must then be had,
If I a Gipsie be
A crack rope I am for thee;
Oh here's a Golden Ring,
Such clappers please a King;
Such clapers please a King: you pleas'd may pass away
Then let your Bell-ropes stay,
Now chime 'tis Holy-day,
Now chime 'tis Holy-day.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: No more of this pray Father, fall to your Dancing. Dance.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Clara will come too late now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis great pitty,
Besides your Songs, Dances and other Pastimes,
You do not as our Spanish Actors doe, make triall of a Stage.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We are sir about it,
So please your high authority to signe us
Some warrant to confirme us.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: My hand shall doo't— and bring the best in Spaine to see your Sports.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Which to set off this Gentleman a Scholler

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Pox on you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Will write for us:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A Spaniard sir?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No my Lord an Italian.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Denies his Country too— my Son sings Gipsie Ballads,
Keepe as you are, wee'l see your Poets vaine,
And yours for playing; time is not ill spent
That's thus laid out in harmelesse merriment.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: My Lord of Carcomo, for this entertainment,
You shall command our loves.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Y'are nobly welcome.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: The Evening growes upon us, Lords to all
A happy time of day.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The like to you Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: To my hearts sole Lady,
Pray let my service humbly be remembred,
We onely mist her presence.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I shall truly
Report your worthy love.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall no further,
Indeed my Lords you shall not.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With your favour
Wee will attend you home.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Where's Don Pedro? oh sir!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: The Lady Clara,
Passing neere to my Lord Corigidors house,
Met with a strange mischance.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How, what mischance?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: The Jester that so late arrived at Court,
And there was welcome for his Countries sake,
By importunity of some friends, it seemes
Had borrow'd from the Gentleman of your Horse,
The backing of your mettl'd Barbary:
On which being mounted, whil'st a number gaz'd
To heare what Jests hee could performe on Horse back,
The head strong beast unus'd to such a Rider,
Beares the Presse of People before him;
With which throng, the Lady Clara meeting,
Fainted, and there fell down; not bruis'd I hope;
But frighted and intranc'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Ill destin'd mischiefe!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Where have you left her?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: At your house my Lord,
A servant comming forth, and knowing who
The Lady was, convey'd her to a Chamber,
A Surgeon too is sent for.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Had shee been my Daughter,
My care could not be greater, then it shall be
For her recure.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But if shee miscarry,
I am the most unhappy Man that lives.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Diego Coast about the Fields,
And over-take Don Pedro and his Wife,
They newly parted from us.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'le runne speedily.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A strange mischance, but what!
I have my Lord Francisco this day noted,
I may tell you, an accident of merriment and wonders

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I have not thoughts enough
About me to imagine what th'event
Can come to, 'tis indeed about my Son;
Hereafter you may counsell me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Most gladly— how fares the Lady?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Call'd back to Life, but full of sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Talkes shee nothing?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nothing, for when the women that attend on her
Demanded how shee did, shee turn'd about,
And answered with a sigh, when I came neere,
And by the Love I bore her, begg'd a word
Of hope to comfort mee in her well-doing;
Before shee would reply, from her faire Eyes
Shee greetes me with a Bracelet of her teares;
Then wish'd me not to doubt, shee was too well,
Entreates that shee may sleepe without disturbance,
Or company untill her Father came.
And thus I left her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For shee's past the worst,
Young Maides are oft so troubled.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here come they
You talke of— sir, your Daughter for your comfort
Is now upon amendment.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Oh my Lord!
You speake an Angels voyce.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pray in and visit her.
I'le follow instantly— you shall not part
Without a cup of Wine my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis now too troublesome a time;
Which way take you Don Lewys?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No matter which, for till I heare
My Clara be recover'd I am nothing,
My Lord Corigidor, I am your servant
For this free entertainment.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You have conquer'd me
In noble courtesie.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh! that no art
But Love it selfe can cure a Love-sick heart.

div.stage: Clara in a Chaire, Pedro and Maria by her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Clara, hope of mine age!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Soule of my comfort,
Kill us not both at once; why dost thou speede
Thine Eye in such a progresse 'bout these Walls?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yon large Window
Yeilds some faire prospect, good my Lord looke out,
And tell mee what you see there.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Easie suite,
Clara it over-viewes a spacious Garden,
Amidst which stands an Alablaster Fountaine,
A goodly one.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The griefes grow wide,
And will mislead thy judgement through thy weaknesse
If thou obey thy weakenesse.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Who ownes these glorious buildings?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Don Fernando
De Azeutda, the Corigidor
Of Mardrill, a true noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: May I not see him?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: See him Clara, why?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A truly noble Gentleman you said sir.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: I did: loe here he comes in person,
We are my Lord your servants.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Good no complement,
Young Lady there attends below a Surgeon
Of worthy fame and practice, is't your pleasure
To be his Patient?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: With your favour sir,
May I impart some few, but needefull words
Of secresie to you, to you your selfe,
None but your selfe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Must I not heare 'em?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh yes, pray sit my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Say on.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have been Married.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To a Wife young Lady,
Who whiles the Heavens did lend her me was fruitfull
In all those vertues which stiles Woman good.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And you had Children by her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Had 'tis true,
Now have but one, a Son, and hee yet lives,
The Daughter, as if in her Birth, the Mother
Had perfected the errand shee was sent for
Into the World, from that houre tooke her Life
In which the other that gave it her, lost hers;
Yet shortly shee unhappily, but fatally
Perish'd at Sea.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sad story!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Roderigo,
My Sonne.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How is hee call'd fit?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Roderigo.
Hee lives at Salamanca, and I feare
That neither Time, Perswasions nor his Fortunes
Can draw him thence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord, d'ee know this Crucifix?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You drive me to amazement, 'twas my Sonnes,
A Legacy bequeathed him from his Mother
Upon her Death-bed, deare to him as Life;
On Earth there cannot be another treasure
Hee values at like rate as hee does this.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh then I am a cast-away!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Alas shee will grow frantick.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: In my bosome,
Next to my Heart my Lord I have laid up,
In bloody Characters a Tale of horror,
Pray read the Paper, and if there you finde
Ought that concernes a Maide undone, and miserable
Made so by one of yours, call back the piety
Of nature, to the goodnesse of a Judge,
An upright Judge, not of a partiall Father,
For doe not wonder that I live to suffer
Such a full weight of wrongs, but wonder rather
That I have liv'd to speak them; thou great man
Yet read, read on, and as thou read'st consider
What I have suffer'd, what thou ought'st to doe;
Thine owne Name, Father-hood, and my dishonour
Be just as Heaven and fate are, that by miracle
Have in my weakenesse wrought a strange discovery;
Truth copied from my heart is texted there:
Let now my shame be throughly understood,
Sinnes are heard farthest, when they cry in blood.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: True, true, they doe not cry but hollow here,
This is the Trumpet of a Soule drown'd deepe
In the unfathom'd Seas of matchlesse sorrowes.
I must lock fast the dore.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I have no words
To call for vengeance.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: I am lost in marvaile.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, pray fit as you sat before: white paper
This should be innocence, these Letters Gules
Should be the honest Oracles of Revenge.
What's Beauty but a perfect white and red?
Both here well mixt, limne truth so beautifull,
That to distrust it as I am a Father;
Speakes mee as foule, as rape hath spoken my Sonne,
'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then marke mee how I kneele
Before the high tribunall of your Injuries;
Thou too too much wrong'd Maid scorne not my teares,
For these are teares of Rage, not teares of Love.
Thou Father of this too too much wrong'd Maide,
Thou Mother of her counsells and her cares;
I doe not plead for pitty to a Villaine,
Oh! let him die as hee hath liv'd dishonorably,
Basely and cursedly, I plead for pitty,
To my till now untainted blood and honour,
Teach mee how I may now be just and cruell;
For henceforth I am Childlesse.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray sir rise,
You wrong your place and age.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Point mee my Grave
In some obscure by path, where never memory
Nor mention of my Name may be found out.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord, I can weep with you, nay weepe for yee
As you for mee, your passions are instructions,
And prompt my faltering Tongue to beg at least
A noble satisfaction, tho not revenge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Speak that agen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Can you procure no Balme
To heale a wounded Name?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh th'art as faire
In Mercy as in Beauty, wilt thou live,
And I'le be thy Physitian?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'le be yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Don Pedro, wee'l to counsaile
This Daughter shall be ours, sleepe, sleepe, young Angell,
My care shall wake about thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Heaven is gracious,
And I am eas'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wee will be yet more private,
Might curtaines o're the world, soft dreams rest with thee.
The best revenge is to reforme our crymes,
Then time crowns sorrowes, sorrowes sweeten times.

div.head: ACTUS QUARTUS.
div.stage: Enter Alvarez, Sancho, Soto, Antonio, Carlo, Eugenia, Pretiosa, Christiana, and Don John. A showte within.

sp.speaker: OMnes.
sp.l: Welcome, welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: More Sacks to the Mill.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: More Theeves to the Sacks.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: I give you now my welcome without noyse.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Tis Musick to me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Oh sir!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You must not be in your Mutton before we are out of our Veale.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Stay for Vineger to your Oysters, no opening till then.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: No kissing till y'are sworne.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Sweare me then quickly.
I have brought Gold for my Admission.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What you bring leave, and what you leave count lost.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I brought all my Teeth, two are struck out, them I count lost, so must you.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I brought all my wits, halfe I count lost, so must you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: To be as you are, I lose Father, Friends,
Birth, Fortunes, all the World; what will you doe
With the beast I rode on hither?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A Beast is't a Mule? send him to Muly Crag a whee in Barbary.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Is't an Asse? give it to a Lawyer, for in Spaine they ride upon none else.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Kill him by any means, lest being pursu'd
The beast betray mee.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Hee's a beast betrays any man.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Except a Bayliffe to be pump'd.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Pray buy the Carcasse and the furniture.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Doe, doe, bury the Asses House-hold-stuffe, and in his skin sow any Man that's mad for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do so then, bury it, now to your Oath.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: All things are ready.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thy best hand lay on this Turffe of Grasse,
(There thy Heart lies) vow not to passe
From us two yeares for Sun nor Snow,
For hill nor dale( how e're Winds blow.)
Vow the hard Earth to be thy Bed,
With her greene Cushions under thy Head;
Flowre bancks or Mosse to be thy bourd,
Water thy Wine,

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And drinke like a Lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Kings can have but Coronations,
Wee are as prowd of Gipsie Fashions;
Dance, Sing, and in a well-mixt border,
Close this new Brother of our Order.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What we get, with us come share,
You to get must vow to care;
Nor strike Gipsie, nor stand by,
When strangers strike, but fight or die;
Our Gipsie Wenches are not common,
You must not kisse a fellowes Leman;
Nor to your owne (for one you must)
In Songs send, errands of base lust.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Dance, Sing, and in a well mix'd border,
Close this new Brother of our Order.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: On this Turffe of Grasse I vow
Your Laws to keepe, your Lawes allow.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A Gipsie, a Gipsie, a Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Now choose what Maide has yet no mate, shee's yours.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Here then fix I my fate.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Agen fall too before you ha wash'd!

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Your Nose in the Manger, before the Oates are measur'd.
Jade so hungry!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Set foote to foote, those Garlands hold,
Teach him how, now marke what more is told;
By crosse Armes the Lovers signe,
Vow as these flowers themselves entwine,
Of Aprills wealth building a throne
Round; so your love to one or none,
By those touches of your Feete,
You must each night embracing meete;
Chaste how e're disjoyn'd by Day,
You the Sun with her must play;
Shee to you the Marigold
To none but you her Leaves unfold;
Wake shee or sleepe, your Eyes so charme,
Want, wee, nor weather doe her harme.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This is your Market now of kisses,
Buy and sell free each other Blisses.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Most, willingly.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Holy dayes, high dayes, Gipsie Faires,
When kisses are Fairings, and hearts meete in paires.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All Ceremonies end heere; Welcome Brother, Gipsie.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: And the better to instruct thee, marke what a brave Life 'tis all the yeare long.

lg.l: Brave Don cast your eyes on our Gipsie Fashions,
In our antique hey de guize, wee goe beyond all Nations;
Plumpe Dutch at us grutch, so do English, so do French,
He that loapes on the Ropes, shew me such an other wench.
We no Camells have to shew, nor Elephant with growte head,
We can Dance, he cannot goe, because the Beast is Corne-fed;
No blinde Beares shedding teares, for a Colliers whipping,
Apes nor Dogs, quick as Frogs, over Cudgells skipping.
Jack in Boxes, nor Decoyes, Puppets nor such poore things,
Nor are we those roring Boys, that cosen Fooles with guilt Rings;
For an Ocean, not such a motion, as the City Ninivie,
Dancing, Singing, and fine Ringing, you these sports shall hear and see.
Come now what shall his Name be?

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: His Name shall now be Andrew, friend Andrew marke mee:
Two yeares I am to try you, prove fine Gold,
The uncrack'd Diamond of my Faith shall hold.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: My vowes are Rocks of Adamant.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Two years you are to try me, black when I turne
May I meete youth and want, old age and scorne.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Kings Diadems shall not buy thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Doe you thinke
You can endure the Life and love it?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: As Usurers dote upon their treasure.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: But when your Face shall be tand, like a Saylors workieday hand:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: When your Feete shall be gall'd, and your Noddle be mall'd:

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: When the Woods you must forredge, and not meete with poore Pease-porridge:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Be all to be dabled, yet lie in no Sheete:

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: With Winters Frost, Hayle, Snow and Sleete;
What Life will you say it is then?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: As now the sweetest.
Away, away, the Corigidor has sent for you.

lg.l: Hence merily fine to get Money,
Dry are the Fields, the Bancks are Sunny;
Silver is sweeter far then Honey.
Flie like Swallowes,
Wee for our Coneys must get Mallowes,
Who loves not his Dill, let him die at the Gallowes;
Hence bonny Girles foote it trimly.
Smug up your beetle Browes, none looke grimly,
To shew a pretty foote, Oh! 'tis seemly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Doe you heare you Gipsie? Gipsie?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Mee?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: There's a young Gipsie newly entertain'd,
Sweete Gipsie call him back for one two words,
And here's a Jewell for thee.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I'le send him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What's his Name?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Andrew.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A very handsome fellow, I ha seene Courtiers
Jet up and down in their full bravery,
Yet here's a Gipsie worth a drove of 'em.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: With mee sweet Heart?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your Name is Andrew.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You can tell Fortunes Andrew.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I could once,
But now I ha lost that knowledge, I am in haste,
And cannot stay to tell you yours.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I cannot tell yours then,
And cause you are in hast, I am quick,
I am a Maide.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: So, so, a maide quick.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Juanna Cardochia,
That's mine owne Name, I am my Mothers Heire
Here to this House, and two more.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I buy no Lands.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They shall be given you, with some Plate and Money,
And free possession (during life) of me,
So the match like you, for so well I love you
That I in pitty of this Trade of Gipsying
(Being base, idle and slavish) offer you
A state to settle you, my youth and beauty,
(Desir'd by some brave Spaniards) so I may call you
My husband, shall I Andrew?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Lass pretty Soule,
Better Starrs guide you, may that hand of Cupid
Ake, ever shot this arrow at your heart,
Sticks there one such indeede?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I would there did not,
Since you'l not pluck it out.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Good sweete I cannot;
For marriage 'tis a Law amongst us Gipsies
We match in our own tribes, for me to weare you
I should but weare you out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I doe not care
Weare what you can out, all my life, my wealth,
Ruine me, so you lend me but your love,
A little of your love.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Would I could give it,
For you are worth a World of better men,
For your free noble minde, all my best wishes
Stay with you, I must hence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Weare for my sake
This Jewell.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I'le not rob you, I'le take nothing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Weare it about your neck but one poore Moon;
If in that time your eye be as 'tis now,
Send my Jewell home agen, and I protest
I'le never more thinke on you; deny not this,
Put it about your neck:

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Well then 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And vow to keepe it there.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: By all the Goodness
I wish attend your fortunes I doe vow it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Scornd! thou hast temper'd poyson to kill me
Thy selfe shall drinke; since I cannot enjoy thee
My revenge shall.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Where are the Gipsies?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Gon;— Diego do you love me?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Love thee Juanna!
Is my life mine! it is but mine so long
As it shall do thee service.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: There's a younger Gipsie newly entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A handsome rascall; what of him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That slave in obsceane Language courted me.
Drew Rialls out, and would have bought my body
Diego from thee!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Is hee so Itchy? I'le cure him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou shalt not touch the Villaine, I'le spin his fate;
Woman strikes sure, fall the blow ne're so late.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Strike on sinne, thou wilt be a striker.

div.stage: Enter Fernando, Francisco, Pedro, and Lewys.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: See Don Lewys, an Army!
(The strongest Army in Spaine) to the full length
Is stretch'd to pluck old Count Alvarez home
From his sad banishment.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: With longing Eyes,
(My Lord) I expect the man, your Lordships pardon,
Some businesse cal's me from you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Prithee Don Lewys,
Unlesse th'occasion be too violent,
Stay and be merry with us, all the Gipsies
Will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I will attend your Lordship,
Before their sports be done.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Be your own Carver,
Not yet shake off these fetters? I see a Sonne
Is heavy when a Father carries him
On his old heart.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Could I set up my rest,
That hee were lost, or taken prisoner;
I could hold truce with sorrow; but to have him
Vanish I know not how, gon none knowes whither,
'Tis that mads mee.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: You said he sent a Letter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A Letter! a meere Riddle; he's gon to see
His fortune in the Warres, what Warres have wee?
Suppose we had, goes any man toth' Field
Naked, unfurnish'd, both Armes and Money?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Come, come, he's gon a Wenching; we in our youth
Ran the selfe same Byas.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: The Gipsies my Lord are come.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are they? let them enter:
My Lord De Cortez send for your Wife and Daughter,
Good company is good Physick, take the paines
To seate your selves in my great Chamber.

div.stage: Enter Alvarez, Don John, Roderigo, Antonio, Carlo, Eugenia, Pretiosa, Christiana, Sancho, and Soto.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: See they are here; what's your number?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The figure of nine casts us all up my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nine! let me see— you are ten sure.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: That's our Poet, he stands for a Cipher.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ciphers make numbers; what Playes have you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Five or six my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It's well so many already.
