sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Wee are promist a very merry Tragedy, if all hit right, of Cobby Nobby.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: So, so, a merry Tragedy, there is a way which the Italians, and the Frenchmen use; that is, on a word given, or some slight Plot,
sp.l: The Actors will extempore fashion out
Sceanes neate and witty.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We can do that my Lord, please you bestow the Subject

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Can you? come hither,
You Master Poet to save you a labour,
Looke you, against your coming I projected
This Comick passage— your Dramma; that's the Sceane.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I, I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I lay in our own Country, Spaine.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: 'Tis best so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here's a brave part for this old Gipsie— look you
The Father: read the Plot— this young shee Gipsie,
This Lady— now the sonne— play him your selfe.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My Lord, I am no Player.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pray at this time.
(The Plot being full) to please my noble Friends,
Because your braines must into theirs put Language,
Act thou the Sonnes part,— I'le reward your paines.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Protest my Lord—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, nay, shake off protesting,
When I was young sir, I have plaid my selfe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Your selfe my Lord! you were but a poore Company then.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, full enough honest fellow— will you do it?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I'le venture.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I thanke you, let this Father be a Don
Of a brave spirit, old Gipsie observe mee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Play him up high, not like a Pantaloone,
But hotly, nobly, checking this his Sonne,
Whom make a very rake-hell, a debosh'd fellow,—
This poynt I thinke will shew well.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This of the Picture,
It will indeed my Lord.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: My Lord, what part play I?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What parts dost use to play?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If your Lordship has ever a Coxcombe, I thinke I could fit you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I thanke your Coxcombe-ship.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Put a Coxcombe upon a Lord!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There are parts to serve you all, goe, goe, make ready,
And call for what you want.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Give me the Plot, our wits are put to triall.
What's the Son's Name, Lorenzo? that's your part
Looke onely you to that,— these I'le dispose;
Old Don Avero, mine; Hialdo, Lollio,
Two servants, you for them.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: One of the foolish knaves give me, I'le be Hialdo.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And I Lollio.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Is there a Banquet in the Play? wee may call for what wee will.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Yes, here is a Banquet.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'le goe then and bespeake an ocean of Sweete meates, Marmalad and Custards.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Make hast to know what you must doe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Doe I call for enough, and when my Belly is full, fill my Pockets.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: To a Banquet there must be Wine, Fortunes a scurvy Whore; if shee makes not my head sound like a Rattle; and my Heels dance the Canaries.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: So, so, dispatch, whil'st me employ our braines
To set things off toth' Life.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I'le be streight with you,
Why does my Father put this trick on mee?
Spies hee mee through my Vizard? if hee does
He's not the King of Spaine, and 'tis no Treason;
If his invention, Jet upon a Stage
Why should not I use action? a debosh'd fellow!
A very rake-hell, this reflects on mee,
And I'le retort it, grown a Poet Father?
No matter in what straine your Play must runne,
But I shall fit you for a roring Sonne.

div.stage: Enter Francisco, Pedro, Fernando, Diego, Maria, and Clara.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Come Ladies take your places, this their Musick,
'Tis very handsome, oh! I wish this Roome
Were frighted, but with noble friends
As are to you my welcomes, begin there masters.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Presently my Lord, wee want but a cold Capon for a property.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Call, call for one— now they begin.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Both short and sweete some say is best,
Wee will not onely be sweete but short,
Take you Pepper in the Nose you mar our sport.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By no meanes Pepper.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Of your Love measure us forth but one span,
We do (tho not the best) the best we can.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A good honest Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Slave! where's my Son Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p:
I have sought him my Lord in all foure Elements; in Earth, my Shooes are full of Gravell; in Water, I drop at Nose with sweating; In Aire, wheresoever I heard noyse of Fidlers, or the wide mouthes of Gallon-pots roaring; and in Fire, what
Chimney soever I saw smoaking with good cheere, for my Masters Dinner, as I was in hope.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not yet come home? before on this old Tree
Shall grow a branch so blasted, I'le hew it off,
And bury it at my foote, didst thou enquire
At my Brothers?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: At your Sisters.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: At my Wives Fathers?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: At your Uncles Mothers, no such sheepe has broke through their hedge, no such Calfe as your Sonne sucks, or bleates in their ground.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am unblest to have but one Sonne onely,
One staffe to beare my age up— one Taper left,
To light me to my Grave, and that burnes dimly
That leaves me darkling hid in clouds of woe,
He that should prop me is mine overthrow.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well done old fellow is't not?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Yes, yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Here comes his man Hialdo.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where's the prodigall your Master sirrah?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Eating Acorns amongst Swine, draffe amongst Hoggs, and gnawing bones amongst Doggs; has lost all his Money at Dice, his Wits with his Money, and his honesty with both, for hee bumfiddles me; makes the Drawers curvet, pitches the Plate over the Bar, scores up the Vintners Name in the Ram-head; flirts his Wife under the Nose, and bids you with a Pox send him more Money.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Art thou one of his Currs to bite me too?
To nayle thee to the Earth were to doe Justice.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Here comes Bucephalus my prauncing Master, nayle me now who dares.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I sit like an Owle in the Ivie bush of a Taverne! Hialdo I have drawne red Wine from the Vintners owne Hogshead.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Here's two more, pierce them too.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Old Don, whom I call Father; am I thy Sonne? if I be, flesh mee with Gold, fat mee with Silver; had I Spaine in this hand,
and Portugall in this, puffe it should flie, where's the Money I sent for?— I'le tickle you for a Rake-hell.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Not a Marvedi.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou shalt have none of me.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Hold his Nose to the Grinstone my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I shall have none!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Charge mee a case of Pistolls.
What I have built I'le ruine, shall I suffer
A Slave to set his Foote upon my heart?
A Sonne! a barbarous Villaine, or if Heaven save thee
Now from my Justice, yet my curse pursues thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hialdo, carbonado thou the old Rogue my Father.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Whil'st you slice into Collups the rusty Gamon his man there.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: No Money! Can Tavernes stand without anon, anon? Fidlers live without scraping, Taffaty Girles looke plumpe without pampering? if you will not Lard mee with Money, give mee a Ship, furnish me to Sea.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To have thee hang'd for Piracy?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Trim, tram, hang Master hand Man.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Then send mee to the West-Indies, buy mee some Office there.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: To have thy throate cut for thy quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Else send me and my ningle Hialdo to the Warrs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A match, wee'l fight Dogge, fight Beare.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Oh deare Hernando! welcome, clap Wings to your heeles,
And pray my worthy friends bestow upon me
Their present Visitation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lorenzo, see the anger of a Father,
Altho it be as low'd and quick as thunder,
Yet 'tis done instantly, cast off thy wildnesse,
Be mine, be mine, for I to call thee home
Have with my honor'd friend here, Don Hernando
Provided thee a Wife.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: A Wife! Is shee hansome? is shee rich? Is shee faire? Is shee wity? Is shee honest? Hang honesty. Has shee a sweete Face, Cherry-Cheeke, Strawberry-lip, white-skin, dainty Eye, pretty Foote, delicate Legs? as there's a Girle now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is a Creature both for Birth and fortunes,
And for most excellent graces of the minde,
Few like her are in Spaine.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: When shall I see her?— now Father pray take your curse off.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I doe, the Lady
Lives from Mardrill, very neere fourteene Leagues,
But thou shalt see her Picture.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: That, that, most Ladies in these dayes are but very fine Pictures.

div.stage: Enter Claro, Don John, Engenia, Pretiosa, Christiana, Sancho and Soto.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ladies to you first welcome, my Lords (Alonzo,
And you worthy Marquesse) thanks for these honours.
Away you: to th'cause now of this meeting, my Sonne Lorenzo,
Whose wildnesse you all know comes now to th' Lure,
Sits gently; has call'd home his wandering thoughts,
And now will Marry.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: A good Wife Fate send him.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: One stayd may settle him.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Flie to the marke sir, shew me the Wench, or her Face, or any thing I may know 'tis a woman fit for me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Shee is not here her selfe, but here's her Picture.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Lord De Carcamo, pray observe this.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe attentively— Don Pedro, marke it.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: If you ha done your part, yonders a Wench wud ha a bout with you, Exit.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Mee!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A Wench!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why stand you staring at it? how do you like her?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes sir, in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I am not so hungry after flesh to make the Divell a Cuckold

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Looke not upon the Face, but on the goodness
That dwells within her.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Set fire on the Tenement.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Shee's rich, nobly discended.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Did ever Nobility looke so scurvilie?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am sunk in fortunes, shee may raise us both.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sink, let her to her Granam; marry a Witch! have you fetch'd a Wife for mee out of Lapland? an old Midwife in a velvet Hat, were a goddesse to this: that a red Lip!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: There's a red Nose.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: That a yellow haire.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Why? her teeth may be yellow.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Where's the full Eye?

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Shee has full blabber Cheekes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Set up thy rest, her marriest thou or none.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: None then, were all the Water in the World one Sea, all Kingdomes one Mountaine. I would climbe on all foure, up to the top of that Hill, and head-long hurle my selfe into that abisse of waves e're I would touch the skin of such rough Haberdine, for the breath of her Picture stinkes hither.

div.stage: A noyse Within. Enter Don John, Diego, Cardochia, Sancho, and Soto in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What tumult's this?

sp.speaker: San. Soto.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder, one of our Gipsies is in danger of hanging, hanging!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Who is hurt?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Tis I my Lord, stab'd by this Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Hee struck me first, and I'le not take a blow
From any Spaniard breathing.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Are you so brave?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Breake up your play: lock all the doores.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I faint my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Have him to a Surgeon, how fell they out?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Oh! my good Lord, these Gipsies when they lodg'd
At my house, I had a Jewell from my Pocket
Stolne by this Villaine.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: 'Tis most false my Lords,
Her own hands gave it mee.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Shee that calls him Villaine,
Or sayes he stole.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hoyday, we heare your scoulding.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: And the hurt Gentleman finding it in his bosome
For that hee stab'd him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hence with all the Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ruffians and Theeves, to prison with 'em all.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My Lord wee'l leave engagements, in Plate and Money
For all our safe forth-commings; punish not all
For one's offence, wee'l prove our selves no Theeves.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh Soto! I make Buttons.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Would I could make some, and leave this Trade.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Iron him then, let the rest goe free, but stir not one foote
Out of Madrill; bring you in your witnesse.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Prick him with a Pinne, or pinch him by the Elbow; any thing.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: My Lord Don Pedro, I am your Ward, wee have spent a little Money to get a horrible deale of Wit, and now I am weary of it.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: My runne-awayes turn'd Juglers! Fortune-Tellers!

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No great Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To Prison with 'em both: a Genleman play the Asse!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If all Gentlemen that play the Asse should to Prison, you must widen your Jayles. Come Soto, I scorne to beg, set thy foot to mine, and kick at shackles.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So, so, away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Send all our Company after, and wee'l play there, and be as merry as you here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Our Comedy turn'd Tragicall! please you Lords walke.
This Actor here and I must change a word,
And I come to you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Well my Lord, your pleasure—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why? couldst thou thinke in any base disguise
To blinde my sight? Fathers have Eagles Eyes.
But pray sir why was this done? why when I thought you
Fast lock'd in Salamanca, at your Study,
Leap'd you into a Gipsie?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sir, with your pardon,
I shall at fit time, to you shew cause for all:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Meane time sir, you have got a Trade to live by,
Best to turne Player, an excellent Ruffian! ha!
But know sir, when I had found you out, I gave you
This project of set purpose, 'tis all my selfe,
What the old Gipsie spake must be my Language,
Nothing are left me but my Offices,
And thin-fac'd honours, and this very Creature
By you so scorn'd, must raise me by your Marrying her.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You would not build your glory on my ruines.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Rascall has bely'd the Lady,
Shee is not halfe so bad, all's one, shee's rich.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Oh! will you see the joyes of my full youth?
To Dunghill muck, seeke out some wretches Daughter;
Whose soule is lost for gold then? you are more noble
Then t'have your Son, the top branch of your house
Grow in a heape of rubbish; I must marry a thing,
I shall be asham'd to owne, asham'd to bring her
Before a Sun-beame.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot helpe it sir, resolve upon't, and doo't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And doo't and die.
Is there no face in Spaine for you to pick out
But one to fright mee? when you sat the Play here
There was a beauty, to be Lord of which
I would against an Army throw defiance.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shee! Alas.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: How! how! at every haire of her's
There hangs a very Angel, this! I am ready
To drop down looking at it: Sir I beseech you
Bury mee in this Earth, on which I am humbled
To beg your blessing on mee for a Gipsie,
Rather then— oh! I know not what to terme it.
Pray what is that young pensive piece of beauty?
Your voyce for her, I ey'd her all the scene.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I saw you did.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Me thought 'twas a sweete Creature.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well tho my present state stands now on Ice,
I'le let it crack and fall, rather then bar thee
Of thy content, this Lady shall goe by then.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hang let her there, or any where.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That young Lannard,
Whom you have such a minde to, if you can whistle her
To come to Fist, make tryall, play the young Falconer.
I will nor mar your marriage, nor yet make
Beauty no wealth, wealth uglinesse, which you wil take.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I thanke you sir, put on your Mask good Madam,
The Sun will spoyle your Face else.

div.head: ACTUS QUINTUS.
div.stage: Enter Fernando, Francisco, Pedro, Roderigo, Clara, Maria, as from Church ever the Stage, Fer. stayes Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: THou hast now the Wife of thy desires.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sir, I have;
And in her every blessing that makes Life
Loath to be parted with.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Noble shee is,
And faire, has to enrich her Blood and Beauty
Plenty of Wit, Discourse, Behaviour, Carriage.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I ow you duty for a double birth,
Being in this happinesse begot againe,
Without which I had been a man of wretchednesse.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then henceforth, Boy, learne to obey thy fate,
'Tis falne upon thee, know it, and embrace it:
Thy Wife's a wanton.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A wanton!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Examine through the progresse of thy youth,
What capitall sins, what great one 'tis, for 'tis
A great one th'ast committed.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I a great one!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Else Heaven is not so wrathfull to poure on thee
A misery so full of bitternesse;
I am thy Father, thinke on't, and be just;
Come doe not dally.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Pray my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Foole 'twere
Impossible that Justice should raine downe
In such a frightfull horror without cause.
Sir, I will know it, rather blush thou didst
An act thou darst not name then that it has
A name to be knowne by.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Turne from mee then,
And as my guilt sighes out this monster Rape,
Oh! doe not lend an Eare.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Rape! fearefull.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hence, hence springs my due reward.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Th'art none of mine.
Or if thou beest, thou dost bely the stampe
Of thy Nativity.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Forgive me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Had shee
Poore wronged Soule( who e're shee was) no Friend,
Nor Father to revenge, had shee no Tongue
To rore her injuries?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Alas I know her not.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peace thou wilt blaze a sin beyond all president,
Young man thou shouldst have married her, the Devill
Of lust that riots in thy Eye, should there
Have let full love and pity; not on this stranger
Whom thou hast doted on.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Oh! had I married her,
I had been then the happiest man alive:

div.stage: Enter Clara, Maria, and Pedro: from behinde the Arras.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: As I the happiest Woman being married,
Looke on me sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You shall not finde a change
So full of feares as your most noble Father,
In his wise Triall urg'd.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Indeed you shall not,
The forfeit of her shame shall be her pawne.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why pray d'ee mock my sorrowes? now oh now
My horrors flew about me!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No thy comforts,
Thy blessings Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By this Crucifix
You may remember me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ha! art thou that Lady wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I was, but now am
Righted in noble satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: How can I turne mine Eyes, and not behold
On every side my shame!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more hereafter,
Wee shall have time to talke at large of all,
Love her that's now thine own, doe Roderigo.
Shee's farre from what I charactred.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My care shall live about me to deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Excellent Clara— Fathers both, and Mother,
I will redeeme my fault.

sp.speaker: Fer. Ped. Ma.
sp.l: Our blessings dwell on yee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Married to Roderigo!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Judge your selfe,
See where they are.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is this your Husband Lady?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He is sir, Heavens great hand that on Record,
Fore-points the equall Union of all hearts,
Long since decreed, what this day hath been perfected.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis well then, I am free it seemes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Make smooth
My Lord, those clowds which on your brow deliver
Emblems of storme; I will as far as honour
May priviledge, deserve a noble friendship,
As you from mee deserve a worthy memory.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Your Husband has prov'd himselfe a friend,
Trusty and try'd, he's welcome I may say
From the University,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: To a new Schoole
Of happy knowledge Lewys.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Sir, I am not so poore to put this injury up,
The best blood flowes within you is the price.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Lewys for this time calme your anger,
And if I do not give you noble satisfaction,
Call mee to what account you please.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: So, so, I come for Justice t'ee,
And you shall grant it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shall and will.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: With speede too.
My poore friend bleeds the whiles.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall your selfe
Before wee part, receive the satisfaction
You come for, who attends
My Lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He attends your Lordships pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What would this Girle? foh no tricks.
Get you to your Cabin Hus-wife, wee have no eare for Ballads.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Take her away.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A wonderous lively Creature.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Noble Gentlemen,
If a poore Maids, a Gipsie Virgins teares
May soften the hard edge of angry Justice;
Then grant mee gracious hearing (as y'are mercifull.)
I beg my Husbands Life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy Husbands, little one!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Gentle sir, our plighted troaths are Chronicl'd
In that white Booke above, which notes the secrets
Of every thought and heart, he is my Husband,
I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Rather his Whore.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Now trust mee,
Y'are no good man to say so, I am honest,
Deede la I am, a poore soule that deserves not
Such a bad word, were you a better man
Then you are, you doe mee wrong.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: The Toy growes angry.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And it becomes her sweetly, troath my Lord,
I pitty her.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your Husband
You'l say is no Thiefe.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Upon my Conscience hee is not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Dares not strike a man.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Unworthily
Hee dares not, but if trod upon, a Worme
Will turne againe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That turning turnes your Worme
Off from the Ladder, Minion.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Sir, I hope
You are not his Judge, you are too young, too chollerick,
Too passionate, the price of Life or Death
Requires a much more grave consideration
Then your yeares warrant, he sit they (like gods)
Upon whose head the reverend badge of Time
Hath seal'd the proofe of Wisdome; to these Oracles
Of riper Judgment, lower in my heart,
Then on my knees, I offer up my suite,
My lawfull suite, which begs they would be gentle
To their owne fames, their own imortall stories,
Oh! doe not thinke my Lords compassion throwne
On a base low estate, on humble People
Lesse meritorious, then if you had favor'd
The faults of great men; and indeed great men
Have often times great faults; he whom I plead for
Is free, the soule of Innocence it selfe
Is not more white, will you pitty him?
I see it is in your Eyes, 'tis a sweete Sun-beame,
Let it shine out; and to adorne your praise
The prayers of the poore shall crowne your dayes,
And theirs are something hard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Beshrew the Girle,
Shee has almost melted mee to teares.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Hence trifler— call in my friends,
What hope of ease?

div.stage: Enter Don John, Diego, and Cardochia.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Good hope, but still I smart,
The worst is in my paine.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The price is high
Shall buy thy vengeance, to receive a wound
By a base Villaines hand, it madds me.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Men subject to th' extremity of Law,
Should carry peace about'em to their Graves,
Else were you nobler then the blood you boast of,
Could any way (my Lord) derive you know,
I would returne sharpe answer to your slanders;
But it suffices I am none of ought
Your rage mistermes mee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: None of 'em, no Rascall?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: No Rascall.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nor no Theefe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Aske her, that's my Accuser, could your Eyes
Pierce through the secrets of her foule desires;
You might without a parciall Judgement, looke into
A Womans Lust and Malice.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My good Lords,
What I have Articled against this fellow,
I justifie for truth.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: On then, no more,
This being true shee sayes; I have deserv'd
To die.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wee sit not here to bandy Words,
But minister Law, and that condemns thee
For theft unto the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Oh my misery!
Are you all Marble-brested? are your bosomes
Hoop'd round with Steele, to cast away a man?
More worthy Life and Honours then a thousand
Of such, as onely pray unto the shaddow
Of abus'd greatnesse.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Tis in vaine to storme,
My Fate is here determin'd!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Lost Creature,
Art thou grown dull too; is my Love so cheape,
That thou court'st thy destruction, 'cause I love thee?
My Lords, my Lords; speake Andrew, prithee now,
Be not so cruell to thy selfe and mee,
One word of thine will doo't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Away with him,
To morrow is his day of Execution.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Even when you will.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Stay man thou shalt not goe;
Here are more Women yet, sweete Madam speake:
You Lady, you methinks should have some feeling
Of tendernesse, you may be touch'd as I am,
Troath wert your cause, I'de weepe with you, and joyne
In earnest suite for one you held so deare.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord, pray speake in his behalfe.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I would, but dare not,
'Tis a fault so cleere and manifest.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Back with him to his Dungeon.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Heaven can tell.
I sorrow not to die, but to leave her,
Who whiles I live is my Lifes comforter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now shall I be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Oh mee unhappy!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: See the Girle falls,
Some one looke to her!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Las poore Maide.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Pretiosa!
Shee does recover, mine honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: In vaine, what is't?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to give mee private audience;
I will discover something shall advantage
The noblest of this Land.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well I will heare thee,
Bring in the Girle.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Ought with me, what is't?
I care not for thy Company old Ruffin,
Rascall art impudent?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To beg your service.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Hang your selfe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your Fathers Soule sir, heare me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Dispatch.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: First, promise mee you will get Repreeve
For the condemned Man, and by my Art,
I'le make you master of what your Heart on Earth
Can wish for, or desire.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thou ly'st thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Try mee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Doe that, and then as I am noble,
I will not onely give thy friend his Life,
But royally reward thee, love thee ever.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I take your word, what would you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: If thou mock'st mee,
'Twere better thou wert damn'd.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sir, I am resolute.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Resolve me then, whether the Count Alvarez,
Who slew my Father, be alive or dead?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is this the mighty matter? the Count lives.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The Count lives!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh fate I now tell mee where?
And be, my better genius.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I can do't,
In Spaine a lives: more, not far from Madrill,
But in disguise much alter'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Wonderfull Scholler,
Miracle of Artists, Alvarez living!
And neere Madrill too! now for Heavens sake where?
That's all, and I am thine.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Walke off my Lord
To the next Field, you shall know all.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Apace then, I listen to thee
With a greedy Eare, the Miserable and the Fortunate
sp.stage: Ex. at one dore. Enter presently at the other.
sp.l: Are alike in this, they cannot change their Fate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Good, good, you would faine kill him and revenge Your Fathers Death.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I would.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Bravely, or securely?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not basely for the World.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Wee are secure.
Young Lewys, two more trusty blades then these,
Spaine has not in her Army; with this
Alvarez slew thy Father, and this other,
Was that the King of France wore, when great Charles
In a set Battaile took him Prisoner;
Both I resigne to thee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: This is a new Mistery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Now see this naked bosome, turns the poynts
Of either on this Bulwarke, if thou covet'st
Out of a sprightly youth, and manly thirst
Of vengeance blood, if blood be thy ambition,
Then call to minde the fatall blow that struck
De Castor thy brave Father to his Grave;
Remember who it was that gave that blow,
His enemy Alvarez, heare, and be suddaine,
Behold Alvarez!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Death, I am deluded.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou art incredulous, as Fate is certaine
I am the man.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thou that Butcher!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Tremble not young man, trust me I have wept
Religiously to wash off from my Conscience
The staine of my offence: twelve yeares and more,
Like to a restlesse Pilgrime I have runne
From foraigne Lands to Lands, to finde out Death.
I am weary of my Life, give mee a Sword,
That thou may'st know with what a perfect zeale
I honour old De Castors memory;
I'le fight with thee, I would not have thy hand
Dip'd in a wilfull Murder, I could wish
For one howers space I could pluck back from Time,
But thirty of my yeares, that in my fall
Thou mightst deserve report: now if thou Conquerst
Thou canst not triumph, I am halfe dead already,
Yet I'le not start a foote.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Breathes there a spirit
In such a heape of rage?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Oh! that I had
A Sonne of equall growth with thee, to tug
For Reputation: by thy Fathers ashes,
I would not kill thee for an other Spaine,
Yet now I'le do my best, thou art amaz'd,
Come on.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Twelve tedious Winters banishment!
'Twas a long time.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Could they redeeme thy Father?
Would every Age had beene twelve Ages Lewys,
And I for Pennance every Age a dying,
But 'tis too late to wish.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I am o'recome,
Your noblenesse hath conquer'd mee, here ends
All strife betweene our Families, and henceforth
Acknowledge mee for yours.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Oh! thou reviv'st
Fresh horrours to my Fact, for in thy gentlenesse
I see my sinne anew.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Our peace is made,
Your Life shall be my care, 'twill be glad newes
To all our noble friends.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Since Heaven will have it so,
I thanke thee glorious Majesty; my Sonne
For I will call thee, e're the next morrow:
Salute the World, thou shalt know stranger mysteries.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I have enough to feede on; sir I'le follow yee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Don John Sonne to the Count of Carcomo,
Woman take heede thou trifle not.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is this
My Lord so strange?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Beauty in Youth, and Wit
To set it forth, I see transformes the best
Into what shape Love fancies.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Will you yet
Give me my Husbands Life?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why little one hee is not Married to thee.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: In his Faith
He is; and faith and troath. I hope binde faster,
Then any other Ceremonies can,
Doe they not pray my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, where the Parties
Pledg'd, are not too unequall in degree,
As hee and thou art.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: This is new Divinity.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My Lord, behold this Childe well: in her Face,
You may observe by curious insight, something
More then belongs to every common birth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: True, 'tis a pretty Child.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: The Glasse of misery
Is after many a change of desperate fortune,
At length runne out, you had a Daughter
Call'd Constanza.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: A Sister Guyamara,
Wife to the Count Alvarez.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peace, oh peace!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And to that Sisters charge you did commit
Your Infant Daughter, in whose birth your Wife
Her Mother dy'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Woman thou art too cruell.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: What d'ee meane Granam? Lass the noble man Growes angry.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not I, indeed I doe not,
But why d'ee use mee thus?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Your Child and Sister,
As you suppos'd were drown'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Drown'd, talking Creature!
Suppos'd!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: They live Fernando from my hand,
Thy Sisters hand receive thine owne Constanza,
The sweetest best Child living.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Doe you mock me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Torment me on, yet more, more yet and spare not,
My heart is now a breaking: now!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Oh Brother!
Am I so farre removed off from your Memory,
As that you will not know mee? I expected
An other welcome home, looke on this Casket,
The Legacy your Lady left her Daughter,
When to her Sonne, shee gave her Crucifix.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Right, right, I know yee now.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In all my sorrowes,
My comfort has been here; shee should be,
Be yours, Constanza kneele sweete Childe
To thy old Father.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: How my Father?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let not
Extremity of joyes ravish Life from mee
Too soone Heaven I beseech thee; thou art my Sister,
My Sister Guyamara; how have mine Eyes
Been darkened all this while:— 'tis shee!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: 'Tis Brother,
And this Constanza, now no more a stranger,
No Pretiosa henceforth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My soules treasure,
Live to an Age of goodnesse, and so thrive
In all thy wayes, that thou mayst die to live.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: But must I call you Father?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou wilt rob mee else
Of that felicity; for whose sake onely
I am ambitious of being young againe;
Rise, rise, mine own Constanza.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: 'Tis a new name,
But 'tis a pretty one, I may be bold
To make a suite t'ee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Oh Father!
And if you be my Father thinke upon
Don John my Husband, without him alas
I can be nothing.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As I without thee,
Let me alone Constanza, tell mee, tell mee,
Lives yet Alvarez?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In your house.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Enough.
Cloy mee not, let me by degrees, disgest
My joyes— within, my Lords Francisco, Pedro.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, Pedro, Maria, Roderigo, Clara
sp.l: Come all at once, I have a World within mee,
I am not mortall sure, I am not mortall,
My honorable Lord, partake my blessings.
Count Alvarez lives here in my house;
Your Sonne my Lord, Francisco, Don John
Is the condemn'd man falsely accus'd of theft,
This my Lord Pedro, is my Sister Guyamare,
Madam, this Constanza mine owne Child,
And I am a wondrous merry Man,
Without the Prisoner.

div.stage: Enter Alvarez, Lewys, Don John, Diego, Sancho, Soto, and Cardocha.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here free and acquited,
By her whose folly drew her to this errour,
And shee for satisfaction is assur'd
To my wrong'd friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I crave your pardons,
Hee whose I am, speakes for mee.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Wee both beg it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Excellent, Admirable; my deare Brother.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Never a happy man till now: young Lewys
And I are reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: For ever faithfully, religiously.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: My noble Lord most welcome.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To all my heart payes what it owes, due thanks
Most, most brave youth to thee.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I all this while,
Stand but a looker on, and tho my Father
May justly tax the violence of my Passions,
Yet if this Lady, Lady of my life
Must be deny'd, let mee be as I was,
And die betimes.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: You promis'd mee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I did,
My Lord of Carcomo, you see their hearts
Are joyn'd already, so let our consents
To this wish'd Marriage.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I forgive thine errors,
Give mee thy hand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Me thine! but wilt thou love
My Daughter, my Constanza?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: As my bliss.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: I thee as Life, Youth, Beauty, any thing
That makes life comfortable.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Live together one, ever one.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And Heaven Crown your happinesse.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now sir, how like you a Prison?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: As Gallants doe a Taverne, being stop'd for a Reckoning, scurvily.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: Though you Cag'd us up never so close, wee Sung like Cuckoes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, well, you be your selfe now.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: My selfe, am I out of my Wits Soto?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here now are none but honourable Friends,
Will you to give a farwell to the life
You ha led as Gipsies, these being now found none,
But noble in their Births, alterd in Fortunes,
Give it a merry shaking by the hand;
And cry adue to folly?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Wee'l shake our Hands, and our Heeles if you'l give us leave. Dance.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: On Brides, and Bride-Groomes to your Spanish Feasts,
Invite with bent Knees all these Noble Guests.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
